papers.abstract: This article describes Mediate: An Annotation Tool for Audiovisual Media, developed at the University of Rochester, and emphasizes the platform as a source for the understanding of film, television, poetry, pop songs, live performance, music, and advertising as shown in three case studies from film and media studies, music history, and linguistics. In each case collaboration amongst students was not only key, but also enabled by Mediate, which allows students to work in groups to generate large amounts of data about audiovisual media. Further, the process of data generation produces quantitative and qualitative observation of the mediated interplay of sight and sound. A major outcome of these classes for the faculty teaching them has been the concept of audiovisualities: the physically and culturally interpenetrating modes of audiovisual experience and audiovisual inscription where hearing and seeing remediate one another for all of us as sensory and social subjects. Throughout the article, we chart how audiovisualities have emerged for students and ourselves out of digital annotation in Mediate.

events.Text: This article describes Mediate: An Annotation Tool for Audiovisual Media, developed at the University of Rochester, and emphasizes the platform as a source for the understanding of film, television, poetry, pop songs, live performance, music, and advertising as shown in three case studies from film and media studies, music history, and linguistics.

Context: Film and Media Studies, Music History, Linguistics

events.Text: In each case collaboration amongst students was not only key, but also enabled by Mediate, which allows students to work in groups to generate large amounts of data about audiovisual media. Further, the process of data generation produces quantitative and qualitative observation of the mediated interplay of sight and sound.

Context: Further, the process of data generation
Method: Use of Mediate tool within collaborative settings
Results: Quantitative and qualitative observations of mediated interplay of sight and sound
Implications: Significant educational benefits for group projects focused on audiovisual media

events.Text: A major outcome of these classes for the faculty teaching them has been the concept of audiovisualities: the physically and culturally interpenetrating modes of audiovisual experience and audiovisual inscription where hearing and seeing remediate one another for all of us as sensory and social subjects.

Method: Analyzing historical data over several years
Utilizing interdisciplinary perspectives combining semiotics, material culture, and media studies
Results: Concerning the role of sound and vision in education
Especially noting that hearing and sight often remedy one another for all of us as sensory and social subjects.
Analysis: This phenomenon occurs because sharing human experiences integrate both auditory and visual modes.
Implications: Extending the research further logically suggests examining similar cross-sensorial interactions in various cultural and institutional setups globally.

events.Text: Throughout the article, we chart how audiovisualities have emerged for students and ourselves out of digital annotation in Mediate.

Purpose: exploring relationship between annotation and audiovisual creation
Results: audiovisually emerged from digital annotation efforts
Analysis: interpretation of observed patterns in audiovisual production
Challenge: constraints faced in accessing Mediate platform
Ethical: ethical implications of equitable technology access
Implications: broader impact on education through annotated media uses

papers.abstract: The DataScapes Project is an exploration of how Augmented Reality objects can be used as constituents for Landscape Architecture. Using Stephen Ramsay’s Screwmeneutics and Harold Innis' Oral Tradition as our theoretical points of departure, the project integrated the products of Data Art – the visualisation and sonification of data – as the constituents for our two works: The Five Senses and Emergence. The Five Senses was the product of protein data, while Emergence was generated using text from the King James version of the Holy Bible. In this exploratory treatment, we present the methods used to generate and display our two pieces. We further present anecdotal, qualitative evidence of viewer feedback, and use that as a basis to consider the ethics, challenges and opportunities that a future AR Landscape Architecture will present for scholars in the Digital Humanities.

events.Text: The DataScapes Project is an exploration of how Augmented Reality objects can be used as constituents for Landscape Architecture. Using Stephen Ramsay’s Screwmeneutics and Harold Innis' Oral Tradition as our theoretical points of departure, the project integrated the products of Data Art – the visualisation and sonification of data – as the constituents for our two works: The Five Senses and Emergence.

The Five Senses was the product of protein data, while Emergence was generated using text from the King James version of the Holy Bible. In this exploratory treatment, we present the methods used to generate and display our two pieces. We further present anecdotal, qualitative evidence of viewer feedback, and use that as a basis to consider the ethics, challenges and opportunities that a future AR Landscape Architecture will present for scholars in the Digital Humanities.

Primary Object: the Two Pieces: Five Senses and Emergence
Secondary Object: the Viewer Feedback Anecdals Qualitative Evidence
